poem:
Old Harry Rocks

Sea stacks, the chalk white
          bones of the land
          echo
                    House martins in the crags,
                    swallows above,
          the dive and swirl, 
          of life persistent.

Silent waves
           hush against stone—
ancestral
           whispers
                                            Ghosts of the cliffs.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: A sea-view of house martins in their ancestral home | Claire Stares We jumped off the boat and swam through a narrow arch in the outcrop known as No Man’s Land, then struck out for Old Harry, the towering sea stack that gives the iconic chalk formation its name. Though primarily known as a site of geological interest, Old Harry Rocks is also significant for its biodiversity both above and below the waves.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: A sea-view of house martins in their ancestral home | Claire Stares We jumped off the boat and swam through a narrow arch in the outcrop known as No Man’s Land, then struck out for Old Harry, the towering sea stack that gives the iconic chalk formation its name. Though primarily known as a site of geological interest, Old Harry Rocks is also significant for its biodiversity both above and below the waves.
